coredata.dc:title: Hybrid heterojunction of molybdenum disulfide/single cobalt atoms anchored nitrogen, sulfur-doped carbon nanotube /cobalt disulfide with multiple active sites for highly efficient hydrogen evolution
coredata.dc:creator: Liu, Baocang
Cheng, Yan
Cao, Bo
Hu, Minghao
Jing, Peng
Gao, Rui
Du, Yaping
Zhang, Jun
Liu, Jinghai
coredata.dc:description: A multicomponent 3D monolithic electrode was designed that consists of Co single atoms anchored/nitrogen, sulfur co-doped carbon nanotubes (CoSAs-NS-CNTs) on carbon cloth (CC) with ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets externally decorated and ultra-small CoS2 nanodots internally confined (MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC) to form a hybrid heterojunction electrode with double interfaces as vectorial electron transport pathways for promoting electrocatalytic performance. The integration of well-distributed MoS2 nanosheets and CoS2 nanodots linked with Co single atoms anchored/N, S co-doped CNTs endows abundant multiple active sites, outstanding conductivity, and the downshifted d-band center with a thermodynamically favorable hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH*) for effectively catalyzing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). As a result, the optimal MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits outstanding HER performance with overpotentials of 72 and 56 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and small Tafel slopes of 59.4 and 43.2 mV dec-1 in acidic and alkaline solutions, respectively, outperforming most of the previously reported molybdenum/cobalt sulfide-based electrocatalysts. Moreover, the electrode also displays good durability and stability reflected from the small decrease on activity after 5000 CV cycles and nearly no decay in current density after electrolysis for 20 h.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A multicomponent 3D monolithic electrode was designed that consists of Co single atoms anchored/nitrogen, sulfur co-doped carbon nanotubes (CoSAs-NS-CNTs) on carbon cloth (CC) with ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets externally decorated and ultra-small CoS2 nanodots internally confined (MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC) to form a hybrid heterojunction electrode with double interfaces as vectorial electron transport pathways for promoting electrocatalytic performance. The integration of well-distributed MoS2 nanosheets and CoS2 nanodots linked with Co single atoms anchored/N, S co-doped CNTs endows abundant multiple active sites, outstanding conductivity, and the downshifted d-band center with a thermodynamically favorable hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH*) for effectively catalyzing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). As a result, the optimal MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits outstanding HER performance with overpotentials of 72 and 56 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and small Tafel slopes of 59.4 and 43.2 mV dec-1 in acidic and alkaline solutions, respectively, outperforming most of the previously reported molybdenum/cobalt sulfide-based electrocatalysts. Moreover, the electrode also displays good durability and stability reflected from the small decrease on activity after 5000 CV cycles and nearly no decay in current density after electrolysis for 20 h.

ce:section.ce:para: With the ever increasing depletion of traditional fossil fuels and the derived ecological issues, hydrogen has drawn increasing attention as a highly efficient, environmentally benign, and sustainable energy carrier [1,2]. Water electrolysis with renewable energy sources, such as sunlight and wind, represents an ideal way for hydrogen generation from abundant water to underpin energy security and emission reduction [3]. However, as a half-reaction in water electrolysis, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is kinetically not favored and requires active catalysts to decrease the overpotential and expedite the reaction [4]. Although Pt-based materials exhibit sufficient activity in HER, their practical applicability is severely restricted by their scarcity and high cost [5]. Consequently, low-cost, earth-enriched, and yet efficient HER electrocatalysts need to be developed. In the last few years, various non-precious electrocatalysts, such as chalcogenides [6], phosphides [7], carbides [8], and nitrides [9], have been reported to be active electrocatalysts for HER.

Transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), such as MoS2 [10], CoS2 [6], Co9S8 [11], FeS2 [12], Ni2S3 [13], and WS2 [14], have been increasingly highlighted as promising alternatives to Pt for HER not only because of their high abundance and low cost, but also owing to their near optimal hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH*) in theory and unique electronic structure. Among them, MoS2 and CoS2 are considered as promising catalysts for HER [6,10]. However, the poor electrical conductivity and interfacial wettability, insufficient numbers of exposed active sites, and serious aggregation largely reduce their electrocatalytic activities [15]. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), especially nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs) with outstanding electrical conductivity, superior mechanical property, large surface area, as well as strong coupling effects among active species are acknowledged as promising carriers and promoters for developing novel catalysts with enhanced activity and durability [16–18].

Recent studies demonstrated that coupling MoS2 and CoS2 with conductive carbon materials especially CNTs to form the corresponding hybrids could remarkably enhance the catalytic activities of MoS2 and CoS2 because the strongly bonded interface of both not only provides good electrical conductivity and reduces the aggregation of MoS2 and CoS2 particles [19], but also increases the exposed catalytic sites and enhances mechanical stability [20–23]. More importantly, the synergy between MoS2/CoS2 and CNTs can optimize their electronic structure and the adsorption free energy of H atoms, and therefore, greatly enhance catalytic performance [24]. Nevertheless, these reported CNTs-based catalysts are common simple composites without orderly organized configurations and hierarchical architectures and normally only available as powders. Thus, developing 3D self-standing representative dual transition metal sulfides hybridized CNTs-based monolithic electrodes with tailored geometry, engineered electronic structure, enhanced synergistic effects, and improved stability is highly desired but still remains challenging.

Herein, we demonstrate our recent efforts toward the construction of a 3D self-standing multicomponent integrated electrode consisting of Co single atoms anchored/heteroatom nitrogen, sulfide co-doped carbon nanotubes (CoSAs-NS-CNTs) on carbon cloth (CC) with ultra-thin 2D MoS2 nanosheets externally decorated and ultra-small CoS2 nanodots internally encapsulated (MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC) via a pyrolysis − oxidation − sulfidation coupled strategy. The MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode thus forms a hybrid heterojunction with double interfaces of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 interconnected by CoSAs-NS-CNTs to create effective electron transfer pathways for vectorial electron transport along with CoS2→CoSAs-NS-CNTs→MoS2 and enhanced overall conductivity. Highly distributive MoS2 nanosheets and CoS2 nanodots decorated on external and internal surfaces of CoSAs-NS-CNTs not only offers abundant accessible active sites but also effectively prevents MoS2 nanosheets and CoS2 nanodots from aggregation and corrosion, thus resulting in outstanding activity and stability toward HER.

Sodium molybdate dihydrate (Na2MoO4·2H2O, AR), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2·6H2O, AR], triethanolamine (TEOA, AR), nitric acid (HNO3, AR), and sulfuric acid (H2SO4, AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Dicyandiamide (C2H4N4), and HiSPECTM 3000 Pt/C (platinum nominally 20 wt% on carbon black), were obtained from Alfa Aesar. Sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2, AR, 99.0 %), thiourea (CH4N2S, AR), and potassium hydroxide (KOH, 99.9 %) were received from Aladdin. Carbon cloth (CC) was purchased from Innochem and cleaned by sonication sequentially in acetone, ethanol, and deionized water. All regents were used as received without further purification. The water used throughout all experiments was purified through a Millipore system.

Layered Co hydroxide nitrate salts of Co(OH)x(NO3)2-x·mH2O (Co-LHSs) on carbon cloth (CC) (Co-LHSs/CC) followed our reported method [25]. Typically, 0.8 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 2.5 ml of TEOA were dissolved in 30 ml of deionized water under vigorous stirring, and then a cleaned CC (2 cm × 3 cm) was immersed into the solution. The solution together with the CC was transferred to a 50 ml Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and held at 80 °C for 12 h. After the autoclave was naturally cooled down to room temperature, the Co-LHSs/CC precursor was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times and dried in a vacuum oven.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC
ce:section.ce:para: To synthesize the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, a piece of Co-LHSs/CC precursor was placed next to the dicyandiamide (DCDA) powder in a porcelain boat with DCDA powder at the upstream side in a tube furnace. Afterwards, the tube furnace was heated at 450 °C for 2 h under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1, and then further heated at 750 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. The CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC was then obtained and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times and dried in a vacuum oven. After further low-temperature oxidation treatment at 300 °C for 2 h, the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC was obtained. In order to obtain CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC was continue heated in the tube furnace with S powder at the upstream side under a N2 atmosphere at 450 °C for 2 h.

To achieve CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC was boiled in 1.0 M H2SO4 for 1 h at 80 °C to remove Co3O4, and subsequently it was washed by deionized water for several times and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC
ce:section.ce:para: Typically, 0.2 mmol of sodium molybdate dihydrate (Na2MoO4·2H2O) and 1 mmol of thiourea (CH4N2S) were dissolved in 35 ml of deionized water under vigorous stirring for 1 h, and then a piece of CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC was immersed into the solution. The solution together with the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC were transferred into a 50 ml Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and held at 220 °C for 24 h. After naturally cooled down to room temperature, the obtained MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h. The synthesis of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC followed the similar procedures except using CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC to replaced CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC. Likewise, the synthesis of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC followed the similar procedures except using CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC to replaced CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC.

To achieve the CoS2/CC, a piece of Co-LHSs/CC precursor was placed next to the sulfur sublimed powder in a porcelain boat with sulfur sublimed powder at the upstream side in the tube furnace. Afterwards, the tube furnace was heated at 450 °C for 1 h under a N2 atmosphere with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. After being naturally cooled down to room temperature, the CoS2/CC was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h.

XRD patterns were performed on a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) operated at a scanning rate of 0.013 ° s−1 in the Bragg angle ranging between 5 ° and 80 °. The characterizations of morphology, microstructure, and elemental composition were performed by field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) (Hitachi S-4800 equipped with an EDS) and field emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM) (FEI Tecnai F20 equipped with an EDS). Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images and EDX mappings were obtained on a FEI Tecnai F20. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed in a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB Xi+ spectrometer equipped with two ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) chambers. All spectra were calibrated with the C-C peak of C 1s orbitals at 284.6 eV. Raman spectroscopy characterizations were carried out using a Renishaw invia Raman microscope with a 532 nm laser source under vacuum conditions in an in-situ reaction cell.

All the electrochemical measurements were conducted on CHI 760E electrochemical workstation in a three-electrode cell. The MoS2/NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC was directly utilized as the working electrode, while a carbon rod and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) served as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry polarization (LSV) measurement was carried out in H2‐saturated 0.5 M H2SO4, 1.0 M KOH, and 1.0 M PBS electrolytes with a sweep rate of 2 mV s−1 between +0.2 and −0.4 V vs. RHE. Cyclic voltammetry sweeps (CVs) were performed between 0 and 0.10 V vs. RHE from 5 to 30 mV s−1 to evaluate the electrochemical active surface areas of the electrode. The accelerated durability tests (ADTs) were carried out by performing up to 5000 CV cycles in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, respectively, in the potential ranges +0.1 to −0.25 V vs. RHE. All potentials, measured against a SCE electrode, were calibrated with respect to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to E RHE = E SCE + E o SCE + 0.059 pH. Long-term durability test was conducted by a potentiation method at fixed potentials. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out over a frequency range of 100 000 to 0.1 Hz at fixed overpotentials with an amplitude of 10 mV.

Quantification of evolved H2 gas during HER testing was performed in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH media using a H-type electrolytic cell that had two compartments separated by a Nafion® membrane. The H2 gas evolved from the reaction was collected by the water drainage method. Typically, an inverted solution-containing graduated cylinder was positioned around the working electrode, and the produced H2 was collected in this graduated cylinder and the volume of H2 was determined. Then, the moles of H2 generated from the reaction were calculated based on the gas law. The purity of the evolved gas was confirmed by gas cromatography analysis. As for the theoretical value, the 100 % current efficiency was assumed during the whole reaction, which means only the HER takes place at the working electrode. The theoretical amount of H2 was calculated using the Faraday law. Potentiostatic electrolysis was performed by maintaining MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC in 0.5 M H2SO4 at an overpotential of 72 mV and in 1.0 M KOH at an overpotential of 56 mV for 100 min.

In this work, all the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [26–28]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method [29] was used to describe the electron-ion interaction, and the electron exchange-correlation function energies were treated with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) function [30]. The plane wave basis was set as 450 eV, and MP k-point sampling was used. Electron smearing was used via the Methfessel-Paxton technique, and the smearing width consistent to σ = 0.2 eV. Meanwhile, the spin polarization was included. The free energies were evaluated by ΔG(H*) = ΔE(H*) + ΔZPE – TΔS, where ΔE(H*) is the binding energy of H* adsorption, ΔZPE and ΔS are the zero-point energy and entropy correction of H atom, respectively. In view of the ΔZPE and ΔS are very small for such packaged systems, so ΔZPE ≈ −1/2 ZPE(H2) and ΔS ≈−1/2 S(H2), and they are 0.27 and 0.40 eV in this work, which are similar with reference values [31]. For MoS2/CoSAs-NS-C@CoS2 heterostructures, the interaction between MoS2 and CoSAs-NS-C@CoS2 is very weak, so the van der Waals interaction (D3) was carried out in this work.

In the calculations, the lattice constants of CoS2 and MoS2 unit cell were optimized firstly. The lattice constants of CoS2 were a = b = c = 5.467 Å, and α = β = γ = 90.00 °, the lattice constants of MoS2 were a = b = 3.191 Å, c = 14.605 Å, and α = β = 90.00 °, γ = 120.00 °. the lattice constants of (The unit cells are shown in Fig. S1. The catalyst surface models were constructed (Fig. S2), including the bare CoS2(210), MoS2(002), MoS2/Co1-NSC, Co1-NSC@CoS2, and MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2. For the CoS2(210), the unit cell p(3 × 3) were used, and the surface has 24 Co and 48 S atoms, in which 8 Co and 16 S are fixed. For the MoS2(002), the unit cell p(3 × 3) were used, and the surface has 9 Mo and 18 S atoms. For MoS2/Co1-NSC, the surface has 125 C, 1 N, 49 S, 1 Co, and 24 Mo atoms. For Co1-NSC@CoS2, the surface has 45 C, 1 N, 49 S, and 25 Co atoms, in which 8 Co and 16 S are fixed. For MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2, the surface has 45 C, 1 N, 65 S, 25 Co, and 8 Mo atoms, in which 8 Co and 16 S are fixed. The 3 × 3 × 1 k-point sampling was used for CoS2, MoS2/Co1-NSC, Co1-NSC@CoS2, and MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2 models, while the 3 × 1×1 k-point sampling was used for MoS2.

The 3D multicomponent monolithic MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode was prepared via a four-step process. Initially, a cobalt layered hydroxide salts Co-LHSs/CC precursor was in-situ grown a CC (Co-LHSs/CC) via a low-temperature solution route. Then, by experiencing a high-temperature pyrolysis process in the presence of DCDA as both carbon and nitrogen sources, the Co-LHSs/CC nanosheets were transformed into CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC nanotubes via a cobalt-catalyzing oriental growth process of N-CNTs using DCDA as raw materials. Subsequently, the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC nanotubes were further subject to air under elevated temperature to convert Co nanodots into Co3O4 nanodots to generate CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC nanotubes. Such an oxidation treatment avoids the difficulty in direct sulfidation of Co nanodots into CoS2 nanodots since the Co3O4 nanodots are easier to be sulfurized into CoS2 than Co nanodots under current sulfidation conditions. Eventually, the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC nanotubes were treated under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4) and thiourea (CH4N2S) to grow ultra-thin 2D MoS2 nanosheets on CoSAs-N-CNTs, along with the realization of in-situ S doping of N-CNTs and conversion of Co3O4 into CoS2 nanodots. Thus, the final 3D multicomponent monolithic MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode was generated (Fig. 1 a). For comparison, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (without CoS2), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (without MoS2), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@Co/CC (Co species are in forms of Co single atoms and metallic Co rather than CoS2), CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (only Co single atoms retained), MoS2/CC, and CoS2/CC was also constructed through elaborately adjusting the synthetic procedures (Fig. S3).

The high-quality Co-LHSs nanosheet on carbon cloth not only acts as a cobalt source to form Co nanodots in-situ but also serves as a catalyst to catalyze the oriental growth of N-CNTs in the presence of dicyandiamide (DCDA). The highly dispersive Co catalytic centers on Co-LHSs nanosheets afford uniform nucleation sites to ensure the formation of high-quality 3D N-CNTs on carbon cloth during the pyrolysis process at the elevated temperature, providing sufficient guarantees for construction of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode. Meanwhile, during the growth of N-CNTs, the Co-LHSs nanosheet allows superficial Co species in close contact with N-CNTs to transform into highly dispersive Co single atoms, while those bulk Co species in no direct contact with N-CNTs eventually convert into Co nanodots confined within N-CNTs. As a comparison, when replacing the lamellar Co-LHSs nanosheet precursor with a similar lamellar Co-LDHs precursor, only poor quality and inferior dispersive CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co nanotubes are observed on CC (Fig. S4). During the synthetic process, the color of CC changed from black gray (bare CC) to yellow (Co-LHSs/CC), black (CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC), light black (CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC), and deep blue (MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC) (Fig. S5), which suggests the formation of desired electrodes after each reaction step.

The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images show that after hydrothermally growing Co-LHSs nanosheet precursor, each microfiber of CC is fully covered by bunches of interconnected Co-LHSs nanosheets (∼ 20 nm in thickness) that are self-assembled into a honeycomb structure during the formation process (Fig. 1b and c). Meanwhile, through catalyzing by metallic Co centers to grow carbon nanotubes, high-density and interlaced CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co nanotubes (∼1‒2 μm in length and ∼30‒50 nm in diameter) are uniformly formed on the CC in a 3D self-supported hierarchical structure (Fig. 1d and e). Bright spots located at tips of CoSAs-N-CNTs confirm the formation of CoSAs-N-CNTs with Co nanodots confined at the end of CoSAs-N-CNTs. After the low-temperature oxidation in air and subsequent sulfidation under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of CH4N2S, the tubular morphology and good dispersity of CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4 (Fig. 1f and g) and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 (Fig. S6) on CC are well maintained except for slightly twist and shrinkage.

The SEM images of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC clearly show that the wormlike 1D structural CoSAs-NS-CNTs with a rough surface are perpendicularly grown on each fiber of the CC. The magnified SEM images display that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 possesses a bumpy surface with obvious wrinkles and ravine, implying that the hierarchical MoS2 with randomly assembled thin nanosheets has been successfully decorated on the external surface of CoSAs-NS-CNTs. The branch-like CoSAs-NS-CNTs nanotubes link together and form a 3D open and porous assemblage, facilitating the exposure of active sites and charge/mass-transfer. Meanwhile, the diameter of the nanotubes increases from ∼40 nm to ∼500 nm, revealing that the formation of hierarchical MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 nanotubes with MoS2 nanosheets is externally decorated and CoS2 nanodots are internally confined.

The energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) show that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC contains Mo, Co, S, N, and C (Fig. S7a), and the content of 7.65, 5.80, 29.57, 7.54, and 49.44 at%, respectively (Fig. S7b). The elemental distribution mappings clearly indicate the homogeneous distribution of Mo, Co, S, N, and C elements in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (Fig. S7c-g), confirming the uniform dispersion of MoS2 and CoS2 in CoSAs-NS-CNTs. Additionally, the tubular structure of CoSAs-N-CNTs is well preserved after etching-off Co3O4 species (Fig. S8). Furthermore, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC are obtained via decorating the MoS2 on CoSAs-N-CNTs (Fig. S9), which adopts similar assembled tubular structure. In comparison, following a direct growth process of MoS2 on a CC, MoS2 nanosheets with ∼1 – 1.5 μm in lateral size and ∼15 nm in thickness are obtained (Fig. S10). Similarly, when directly growing CoS2 on carbon cloth, only porous and rough CoS2 nanosheets (∼25 nm in thickness) are formed (Fig. S11).

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images reveal that CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co presents a pea-like structure, in which the superfine Co nanodots indicated by black dots with a size range from 10 to 20 nm are embedded in tips of carbon nanotubes (Figs. S12a and b). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images show that Co nanodots are tightly encapsulated by ca. 5–8 nm thick N-doped graphited carbon layers with an interplane spacing of ∼0.35 nm (Fig. S12c) through the obvious contact interface. The Co nanodots clearly display the lattice fringes with an interspacing of 0.204 nm, in well accordance with the (111) plane of cubic metallic cobalt [32]. After experiencing the oxidation in air under 300 °C, the tubular N-CNTs structure was still retained (Fig. S12d and e), suggesting that it has outstanding thermal stability. The corresponding HRTEM image shows the fringe spacings of ∼0.35 and 0.286 nm, assigned to the (002) and (111) lattice planes of graphitized carbon and Co3O4, respectively, are observed (Fig. S12f). After further hydrothermal sulfidation treatment, the structure, size, and morphology of CoSAs-NS-CNTs had no obvious changes except that the surface roughened (Fig. S12 g and h). The HRTEM image confirms the clear lattice fringe with a d spacing of 0.275 nm ascribed to the (200) lattice plane of cubic phase CoS2, identifying the formation of CoS2 nanodots confined within CoSAs-NS-CNTs (Fig. S12i). The TEM images further reveal that the CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 nanotubes (∼40 nm in diameter) are cross-linked together by randomly oriented thin MoS2 nanosheets (about 3 − 5 layers thick) (Fig. 2 a and b). The edge view of MoS2 nanosheets clearly show the lattice fringe with an interlayer distance of 0.63 nm that is attributed to the typical (002) plane of 2H MoS2 (Fig. 2c). In addition, the lattice fringe with an interplanar spacing of ∼0.247 nm that corresponds to the (210) plane of cubic CoS2 is also identified within CoSAs-N-CNTs. Further STEM characterization on MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 displays the existence of bright spots (Fig. 2d), suggesting the presence of CoS2 within CoSAs-NS-CNTs. The corresponding EDX elemental mappings clearly show that the Mo and S run throughout the whole randomly-oriented nanosheets, while the C and N are homogeneously distributed along with tortuous nanotubes (Fig. 2e-i). Besides, uniformly distributed Co can be observed on walls of the NS-CNTs, suggesting the existence of Co single atoms in CoSAs-NS-CNTs. In order to elucidate the dispersion of Co species at the atomic level, the aberration corrected HAADF-STEM was performed. The homogeneously distributed isolated bright dots marked by green circles in Fig. 2j reveal that well-dispersed Co single atoms are anchored in NS-CNTs of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 [33]. To avoid the interference of high metals content in the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 for more accurately determining the existence of Co single atoms in NS-CNTs, we removed CoS2 and MoS2 by an oxidition-acid etching strategy to obtain CoSAs-NS-CNTs. And the CoSAs-NS-CNTs was further characterized by using the aberration corrected HAADF-STEM (Fig. S13a). The homogeneously distributed isolated bright dots in NS-CNTs demonstrate that well-dispersed Co single atoms are anchored in NS-CNTs. Therefore, it can be confirmed that the Co single atoms indeed exist in NS-CNTs of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2. In fact, well-dispersed Co single atoms with Co-Nx configuration anchored in N-CNTs have been formed in the CoSAs-NS-CNTs@Co (Fig. S13b). The stable structure of Co-Nx formed at a high temperature of 750 °C in the N-CNTs, originating from the strong anchoring effect of nitrogen atoms, can not be broke after low temperatures (≤300 °C). Therefore, the cobalt species in N-CNTs and NS-CNTs of the CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4 and MoS2/CoSAs-N-CNTs@CoS2 can still stay as single-atom form after oxidation treatment in O2 (300 °C) and hydrothermal reaction with thiourea (220 °C) (Fig. S13c and Fig. 2j). As reported in the literatures, for graphitized carbon materials, only carbon skeleton was partly broke and generated some defects and O or S atoms doped sites after oxidation or sulfuration treatment at low temperatures [34–36]. The EDX spectrum of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 confirms the presence of Mo, Co, S, N, and C elements with a content about 7.48, 5.03, 27.52, 4.82, and 55.15 at%, respectively (Fig. 2k). Meanwhile, the molar ratio of S to Mo + Co in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CoS2 is calculated to be ∼ 2.2:1, slightly larger than the theoretical stoichiometry of S to Mo + Co in CoS2 and MoS2, suggesting the occurrence of S-doping in CoSAs-N-CNTs. In addition, the morphology and structure of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC are similar to those of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (Fig. S14a-d) except for the absence of CoS2 nanodots. Meanwhile, the corresponding elemental mappings and EDX spectrum show that the Mo and S elements spread around the CoSAs-NS-CNTs, whereas the C and N elements distribute only along with the curving CoSAs-NS-CNTs (Fig. S14e-i).

The crystalline phase a was determined by X-ray power diffraction (XRD) (Figs. S15 and 2 l). The diffraction patterns of Co-LHSs/CC precursor can be assigned to a newly found Co(OH) x (NO3)2-
x ·mH2O compound with a similar lamellar structure to previously reported Ni(OH)1.6(Ac)0.4·0.63H2O (PDF No. 00-056-0570) (Fig. S15) [25]. For CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, three diffraction peaks at 44.4, 51.4, and 76.1°are associated with the (111), (200), and (220) planes of face-centered cubic metallic cobalt (PDF No. 15-0806) [32]. Besides, the broad peak appeared at ∼26.5 ° corresponding to the (002) refection of graphitic carbon phase and CC is also clearly identified. Following further low-temperature oxidation, the characteristic peaks at 31.3, 36.8, 44.7, 59.3, and 65.1 ° are detected, being well indexed to the (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) facets of spinel Co3O4 (PDF No. 74-2120) [34], respectively, implying the transformation of Co nanodots into Co3O4 nanodots. After further sulfidation, the obtained CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC shows the characteristic XRD peaks at 27.9, 32.3, 36.2, 39.8, 46.3, 54.9, 57.6, assigned to the (111), (200), (210), (211), (220), (311), and (222) planes of cubic phase CoS2 (PDF No. 41-1471) [6]. Interestingly, when carrying out the hydrothermal treatment of CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC in the presence of both Na2MoO4 and CH4N2S, except for the diffraction peaks assigned to cubic phase CoS2, additional characteristic diffraction peaks at around 14.2, 32.8, 39.7, and 58.3 ° attributed to the (002), (100), (103) and (110) planes of hexagonal phase MoS2 appeared [23]. This suggests that ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets are successfully decorated on CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC nanotubes accompanying with the in-situ sulfidation transformation of Co3O4 into CoS2 nanodots and the S-doping of CoSAs-N-CNTs. It should be noted that according to microscopic characterizations, the Co single atoms formed on N-CNTs still maintained the single atom nature even after oxidation and sulfidation processes due to their highly dispersive nature and tight coordinative bonding of Co with N embedded in N-doped CNTs [37]. For comparison, the bare CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC is also fabricated by etching-off Co species from CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC with a 1.0 M H2SO4 solution [38]. As shown in Fig. 16, the bare CC shows a weak broad diffraction peak at around 26.0 °, which is typical for CC. The XRD pattern of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC displays a strong broad diffraction peak centered at around 25.3 ° accompanied by a weak one at 43.2 °, indicating the formation of CoSAs-N-CNTs without Co nanodots on CC. After hydrothermally growing MoS2 nanosheets on CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, the characteristic diffraction peaks of MoS2 (PDF No. 37-1492) [39] were detected, suggesting the formation of MoS2@CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC. The XRD patterns of MoS2/CC and CoS2/CC electrodes show the diffraction peaks of MoS2 and CoS2 (PDF No. 41-1471), respectively, confirming the successful growth of MoS2 and CoS2 on CC [40]. All these results indicate the successful synthesis of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, MoS2/CC, and CoS2/CC electrodes.

Raman spectra were measured to assess the graphitization degree of different samples. Two characteristic peaks at 1347 and 1590 cm−1 indexed to D and G bands are found in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC, and CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, suggesting the existence of graphitized CNTs in all samples (Fig. 2m) [41]. The bare CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC exhibits an ID/IG ratio of 0.98, lower than that of CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC (1.16), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (1.14), and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (1.09), suggesting that implant of Co3O4, CoS2, and MoS2 species may cause the increase of defect and disorder densities of CNTs [20,42]. Additionally, the Raman peaks located at around 673 and 662 cm−1 attributing to CoOx and CoSx species can be observed in CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co3O4/CC and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (Fig. 2m) [17], indicating the formation of Co3O4 and CoS2 after oxidation and sulfidation treatments. Two additional strong characteristic peaks of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC corresponding to in-plane E1 2g and out-of-plane A1g vibrational modes of the 2H MoS2 can be seen at 378 and 404 cm–1 [21], implying that the MoS2 has been decorated on CoSAs-NS-CNTs. Notably, the intensity of the E1 2g peak is wider and weaker than that of the A1g peak, demonstrating the presence of abundant in-plane defects and edge sites, which would lead to an enhancement electrocatalytic performance [22]. It should be noted that no Raman peaks attributed to CoS2 can be observed due to the interference and shielding effects of the wrapped CoSAs-NS-CNTs and MoS2 nanosheets. Additionally, as displayed in Fig. S17, the Raman spectrum of CC displays two weak characteristic peaks at∼1577 and ∼1360 cm−1, attributing to defects and disordered carbon (D-band) and sp2 graphitic carbon (G-band), respectively, which is typical for CC. The strong Raman characteristic peaks of carbon and MoS2 can be detected in CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC and MoS2/CC, respectively while the Raman peaks of both carbon and MoS2 can be found in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (Fig. S17), revealing the formation of target reference samples.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to identify the elemental compositions and chemical states. The survey spectrum (Fig. S18) confirms that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC contains five elements of Mo, Co, S, N, C, and O elements. In high-resolution spectrum of Mo 3d of MoS2/CC (Fig. 3 a), two pronounced peaks at lower binding energies of 232.1 and 228.9 eV are attributed to the Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2 for Mo (IV) state of MoS2 [16]. The other two weak peaks at 235.5 and 232.6 eV are associated with Mo6+, indicating the existence of trace MoO3. However, for the Mo 3d XPS spectra of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, all the Mo peaks shift toward more negative binding energy values, being ascribed to the electron transfer effect from the CoSAs-NS-CNTs to MoS2 owing to their strong coupling effect. For the S 2p spectrum of MoS2/CC (Fig. 3b), doublet peaks at low binding energies of 162.1 and 163.3 eV are related to the 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 states of S bonded to Mo in the form of MoS2 [43], whereas the peaks at high-energies of 169.5 and 168.4 eV can be assigned to S6+ species in SO4 2− located at the edges of MoS2 nanosheets [44]. Besides, the additional peaks at 164.2 and 165.4 eV, attributing to thiophene‐like S (CSC) in the lattice of carbon matrix [45], can be observed in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, suggesting the successfully doping of S atoms in CoSAs-N-CNTs. Similar as the Mo 3d spectra, the corresponding S peaks of MoS2 in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC also shift to lower binding energy values. These results imply that the electrons transfer from CoSAs-NS-CNTs to MoS2 should exist in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 [46], which may boost the electrocatalytic performance [10].

The Co 2p spectrum of CoS2/CC displays six peaks at 778.4, 779.9, 781.5, 793.3, 794.6, and 796.4 eV together with two shakeup satellites (Fig. 3c). The peaks appearing at 778.4 and 793.3 eV correspond to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 core levels of Co in CoS2, while those two doublets at 794.6/779.9 eV and 796.4/791.5 eV are attributed to Co3+ and Co2+ in form of CoOx species due to the inevitable oxidation of Co metal in air [18]. Compared to CoS2/CC, the Co 2p peaks of CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC slightly shift to the positive binding energies, demonstrating a strong synergistic effect between CoS2 and CoSAs-NS-CNTs, that is supported by the corresponding deconvoluted S 2p spectra of CoS2 in CoS2/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, and MoS2/NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (Fig. 3d), in which the corresponding S peaks of CoS2 also shift to higher binding energy values in comparison with those in CoS2/CC. Based on the XPS results, it is deduced that a complex electron transfer process along a pathway of CoS2→CoSAs-NS-CNTs→MoS2 in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 hybrid, which makes the CoS2 act as electron acceptors and the MoS2 function as electron donors. The electron accumulation on MoS2 is beneficial for optimizing ΔGH* and enhancing HER activity [47].

The deconvolution of N 1s XPS spectrum of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC exhibits five peaks at 397.7, 401.4, 399.8, 398.6, and 395.3 eV corresponding to Co-N bond in carbon layer, graphitic, pyrrolic, and pyridinic N, and Mo 3p orbit (Fig. 3e), respectively, which suggests that N atoms and CoSAs with CoN4 configuration have been simultaneously incorporated in CNTs. The Co, N, and S dopants in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC may help to improve its electrocatalytic activity [47,48]. The C 1s spectrum shows a main peak of graphitic sp2 carbon at 284.6 eV along with five additional components at 284.1, 285.6, 286.4, 288.2, and 290.7 eV attributed to CS, CN, CO, CO, and OCO (Fig. 3f) [48], respectively, further suggesting that N and S heteroatoms have been successfully co-doped in CNTs.

The electrocatalytic activity of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC used as a 3D self-supported integral electrode toward HER was evaluated in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. The HER activities of blank CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, CoS2/CC, MoS2/CC, and commercial 20 % Pt/C, were also carried out for comparison. The loading of active species on CC of different electrodes is calculated and shown in Table 1 . To directly reflect the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of catalysts, iR compensation was applied to all initial data during the measurement. As expected, the benchmark Pt/C shows the highest HER activity, whereas bare CC exhibits a negligible catalytic activity (Fig. 4 a). Impressively, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits enhanced activity compared with CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrodes. To drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrodes require much higher overpotentials (η) of 190, 148, 118, and 127 mV, respectively, while MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode only needs a low overpotential of 72 mV (Table 1). Meanwhile, the CoS2/CC and MoS2/CC exhibit relatively low activity, requiring overpotential of 152 and 144 mV at 10 mA cm−2. These results imply that the unique hybrid structure with two heterojunction interfaces of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs and CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2 play a vital role in promoting the electrocatalytic activity of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC. The accompanying Tafel slopes of 59.4 mV dec-1 of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode is also smaller than those of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC (112.7 mV dec-1), CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC (76.2 mV dec-1), MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (68.8 mV dec-1), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (70.1 mV dec-1), CoS2/CC (76.2 mV dec-1), and MoS2/CC (74.5 mV dec-1) (Fig. 4b), indicating MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode presents the fastest HER process. The value of Tafel slopes reveals that the HER process over MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode follows the Volmer – Heyrovsky mechanism [49]. It is worth noting that the HER activity of the current MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode is higher than most of reported cobalt and molybdenum sulfides-based electrocatalysts in acidic medium (Table S1). Moreover, the exchange current density (j0) of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode, gained by extrapolating the Tafel plot, is 0.234 mA cm−2, still higher than those control electrodes (Table 1), further highlighting the exceptional catalytic ability of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode [50].

To further interpret the nature of active sites in the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode, the poison tests of SCN– for MoS2/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, and MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrodes were performed in a mixed solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 and 5 mM KSCN (Fig. S19). The metal-centered catalytic sites are widely known to be deactivated by the SCN− in acidic electrolye. With the introduction of SCN− into the acidic electrolyte, the overpotential over the CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode at the current intensity of 10 mA cm−2 (η10) dramatically increases to 165 mV from 127 mV (Fig. S19), suggesting that most of the metallic active sites that exist in form of Co-Nx in NS-CNTs is deactivated by SCN− ions [51]. However, the HER activity of the MoS2/CC electrode in the SCN− contaning acidic electrolyte nearly has no decay compared to that in the pure acidic electrolyte because the S-edge of MoS2 nanosheets is the real active site [39]. Interestingly, the η10 of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode only increases to 85 mV from 72 mV after introducting SCN− into the acidic electrolyte, much less than that of the CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode, which may result from the shielding effect of MoS2 nanosheets for the metallic active sites of Co-Nx on the surface of NS-CNTs. In addition, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits a η10 of 72 mV in acidic medium, much lower than that of CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode (127 mV). Based on above results, it is inferred that the real active sites for HER in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC are the S atoms in the edge of MoS2 nanosheets and the accessible Co single atoms anchored on the surface of NS-CNTs.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to determine the HER kinetics of catalysts at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The Nyquist plots (Fig. S20) reveal that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits the smallest charge transfer resistances (Rct) of 4.52 Ω in acidic medium in contrast to those of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC (78.2 Ω), CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC (33.4 Ω), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (15.3 Ω), MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (10.7 Ω), and MoS2/CC (27.4 Ω) electrodes (Table S2), which implies that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode possesses a faster electron transfer rate and favorable HER kinetics [52]. This may be attributed to the synergistic effect of CoS2, CoSAs-NS-CNTs, and MoS2 that create a complex electron transfer process along a pathway of CoS2→CoSAs-NS-CNTs→MoS2 and decreases charge transfer resistance at the catalyst/electrolyte interface. To probe the greatly enhanced HER performance of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode, the double-layer capacitances (Cdl) of these electrocatalysts were first determined by a typical cyclic voltammetry (CV) method (Fig. S21) [34]. Then, the effective electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) of these electrodes were calculated by using the equation of ECSA = Cdl/Cref, where the average value of Cref for a flat surface is generally found to be 40 μF cm−2 per cmECSA 2. The ECSA of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode is calculated to be 6075 cm2, higher than those of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (5175 cm2), MoS2/CC (2525 cm2), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (4675 cm2), CoS2/CC (2325 cm2), CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC (3075 cm2), and CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (2275 cm2) in 0.5 M H2SO4 medium. Meanwhile, the ECSA normalized HER activity (j ECSA) for MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte is also higher than those for MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, MoS2/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, CoS2/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, and CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC electrodes (Fig. S22). These results imply that the improved catalytic activity of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode not only originates from the higher surface area and more exposed catalytically active sites but also the enhanced intrinsic catalytic activity of the sites. The durability of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode was further assessed by successive cyclic voltammetry (CV) and long-term chronoamperometry (Fig. 4c) The MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode displays nearly overlapped polarization curves before and after 5000 cycles and has negligible current decay for 20 h at a constant voltage operation, suggesting its excellent HER stability.

The HER activity of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode toward HER in 1.0 M KOH solution were also determined (Fig. 4d). Similar to in acidic condition, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits superior HER activity with an overpotential of 56 mV to drive the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline medium, larger than that of Pt/C (29 mV), but much smaller than those of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC (202 mV), CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC (151 mV), MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (111 mV), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (123 mV), CoS2/CC (160 mV), and MoS2/CC (142 mV) (Table 1). This value is also higher than most of reported cobalt and molybdenum sulfides-based electrocatalysts in alkaline solution (Table S3). Likewise, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode possesses the fastest dynamics with the Tafel slopes of 43.2 mV dec-1, lower than those of CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC (104.9 mV dec-1), CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC (84.0 mV dec-1), MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC (57.5 mV dec-1), CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC (67.9 mV dec-1), CoS2/CC (90.9 mV dec-1), and MoS2/CC (69.6 mV dec-1) (Fig. 4e and Table 1). In addition, the value of j0 for MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode can reach 0.209 mA cm−2 in alkaline solution, also higher than those of control electrodes (Table 1). Even if the electrocatalyst commonly shows higher HER activity in acidic medium than in alkaline medium due to the favorable reaction kinetics in an acidic solution, the surprisingly higher HER electrocatalytic activity of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode can be achieved in 1.0 M KOH rather than in 0.5 M H2SO4, which may indicate that the CoS2 plays a key role in the Volmer and Heyrovsky steps in the HER process [53,54]. The Nyquist plots (Fig. S23) reveal that the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode possesses the smaller charge transfer resistance comparing with those of control electrodes (Table S2).

Furthermore, no significant decay is observed for MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC after 5000 CV cycles and 20 h continuous electrolysis (Fig. 4f), indicating the super long-term durability of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode in basic medium. Notably, the morphology and crystalline structure of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode are well preserved after the stability test (Figs. S24 and S25). Meanwhile, the elemental composition in the used MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode is almost the same as the fresh one (Fig. S26). These results further indicate the good structural and chemical stability of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode.

Additionally, the HER activities of MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs/CC, MoS2/CC, CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC, CoS2/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs@Co/CC, CoSAs-N-CNTs/CC, 20 % Pt/C, and bare CC electrodes were also studied in neutral (1.0 M PBS) electrolyte, which give a similar trend as in the acidic and alkaline media (Fig. S27), highlighting the outstanding catalytic activity of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode in a wide pH range. Furthermore, the Faraday efficiency of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode for HER was close to 100 % in both acidic and alkaline media (Fig. 4g-h), indicating that almost all electrons are used for H2 evolution.

To further understand the intrinsic activity of the heteroatoms and heterojunctions in MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode, the density function theory (DFT) calculations for the free-energy diagram of the HER and the electronic structure were performed by building the relevant catalyst models (Figs. 5 a, S1, and S2, in which the Co single atoms decorated N, S-doped carbon shell is marked as Co1-NSC). As a thumb rule, if the Gibbs free energy for H adsorption (ΔG H*) related to proton/electron-transfer and hydrogen release process is close to zero, it should be a promising candidate for the HER [25,55]. The computational results exhibit that the bare MoS2 has a low HER performance with a relatively large endothermic energy of +0.55 eV (Figs. 5a, 5b, and S27), in which the atomic H is adsorbed on top site of S atom in the edge of MoS2. However, after loading MoS2 on the Co single atoms decorated N, S-doped carbon shell (MoS2/Co1-NSC), it exhibits slightly reduced endothermic ΔG H* of +0.32 eV on the top site of C atom in the carbon shell, indicating the improved HER activities [56]. Likewise, the bare CoS2 shows an exothermic ΔG H* value of -0.56 eV, whereas encapsulated CoS2 in Co single atoms decorated N, S-doped carbon shell (Co1-NSC@CoS2), an obviously reduced energy barrier of -0.24 eV is calculated to promote the reaction. According to the experiment results, we further coupling the MoS2 with Co1-NSC@CoS2 to form double heterojunctions model of MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2, in which the edge site of MoS2 is constructed and thus the channel of the H proton and H2 gas can be set up between the active sites of carbon shell and electrolyte solution. Unexpectedly, the calculations show that the obtained MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2 possesses a very advantageous ΔG H* of +0.02 eV both on the carbon layer of Co1-NSC and the edge of MoS2, revealing that the unique heterostructure has multiple active sites to accelerate the proton/electron transfer and optimize the HER kinetics, which is in well agreement with the experiment results.

To understand the optimal intrinsic activity of HER, the electronic properties of MoS2, CoS2, MoS2/Co1-NSC, Co1-NSC@CoS2, and MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2 were further calculated, including the Bader charge of all the elements in the five models (Table S4), the partial electronic density of states (pDOS) and the corresponding d-band center of Mo and Co atoms (Fig. 5c), as well as the charge density differences of MoS2 or carbon layer (Fig. 5d). It is clear seen that the d-band center of Mo atoms in MoS2 is much higher than that of Co atoms in CoS2 (-0.906 vs.−1.592 eV), and the charge of S atoms in MoS2 is more negative than that in CoS2 (-0.562 vs.−0.290), indicating the higher d-band center of Mo atom can promote the electron transfer from Mo to S atom, and thus the more negative charge of S atom in MoS2 leads to the weaker adsorption of H atom on the top site of S atom compared with CoS2 (+0.55 vs.−0.56 eV). Subsequently, when the MoS2 is loaded on the carbon layer of Co1-NSC, the electron can be transferred from Co1-NSC to MoS2 (Fig. 5d), giving rise to the obvious elevation of the d-band center of Mo atoms from -0.906 to -0.211 eV, and the decreasing of the charge of S atoms from -0.562 to -0.571. Therefore, it is considered that the adsorption of H atom is reduced (+0.67 vs. + 0.55 eV) on the top site of S atom because of the electron donating of Co1-NSC, and now the top site of C atom becomes the major active site of H adsorption (+0.32 vs. + 0.67 eV) in MoS2/Co1-NSC. For comparison, when the CoS2 is encapsulated in the Co1-NSC, the electron can be transferred from CoS2 to Co1-NSC, and the charge of C atoms in Co1-NSC@CoS2 is more negative than that in MoS2/Co1-NSC (-0.010 vs. + 0.010), so the H adsorption on Co1-NSC@CoS2 is more stable than that on MoS2/Co1-NSC (-0.24 vs. + 0.32 eV). In particular, when the MoS2, Co1-NSC and CoS2 are combined into the double heterojunctions model of MoS2/Co1-NSC@CoS2, the calculations show that the electron can be transferred from CoS2 to Co1-NSC, and then to MoS2, finally the synergistic effect results in the moderate d-band center of Mo atoms of -0.539 eV, as well as the balanced charge of C atoms of +0.003. In summary, the analysis of electronic properties demonstrates that the heterointerface between CoS2, CoSAs-NS-CNTs and MoS2 promotes the charge transfer, leading to the higher HER activity of the heterojunction MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC.

The excellent electrocatalytic performance of the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode mainly originates from the following considerations (Scheme 1 ): (i) The 3D hierarchical structure with abundant open spaces and porosities largely increases the accessible surface area and maximizes the exposed active sites, which enable the fast charge/mass transport and accelerates the surface electrocatalytic process [32]; (ii) The 2D conductive CoSAs-NS-CNTs in hybrid materials facilitate a continuous pathway for electron transport, effectively reduce the charge transfer resistance, and largely prevent ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets and ultrafine CoS2 nanodots from aggregation during the synthetic and electrocatalytic processes; (iii) The oriented electronic field from MoS2 to CoS2 caused by the strong coupling of CoS2, CoSAs-NS-CNTs, and MoS2 promotes the electron transfer along a pathway of CoS2→CoSAs-NS-CNTs→MoS2 and induces the electron accumulation on MoS2, which optimizes hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔGH*), thus promoting the electrocatalytic performance; (iv) The doping of N and S heteroatoms in carbon nanotubes brings additional nonmetal active sites, which enhance the electrocatalysis; (v) The 3D self-supported hierarchical configuration assembled from 1D CoSAs-NS-CNTs and 2D MoS2 nanosheets on CC promotes the release of evolved gas bubbles and imparts the superior stability [57].

In summary, we have fabricated a novel 3D self-standing binder-free MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode constituting Co single atom anchored/N, S co-doped carbon nanotubes on CC with ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets externally decorated on CNTs and ultra-small CoS2 nanodots internally confined in CNTs via a pyrolysis − oxidation − sulfidation coupled strategy. As a robust electrode, the MoS2/CoSAs-NS-CNTs@CoS2/CC electrode exhibits outstanding electrocatalytic activity as well as good stability toward HER in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes. It only needs as low as overpotentials of 72 and 56 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes to afford a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Also, it exhibits a robust durability and stability reflected from the slight activity decrease after 5000 CV cycles and nearly no decay of current densities after continual electrolysis for 20 h. The excellent catalytic performance originates from strong coupling effects among MoS2, CoSAs-NS-CNTs and CoS2 with more multiple exposed accessible active sites, build-in pathways for improved charge transfer and conductivity based on double heterojunction interfaces, as well as 3D hierarchical porous structure for enhanced mass-transport efficiency. More importantly, the vectorial transfer of electrons along with the pathway of CoS2→CoSAs-NS-CNTs→MoS2 highly promotes the activity of active sites on ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets for HER.
